entry.title: Re: Partner TDD with new IAS/IPS
entry.content:
Hello @ayakaHA 

Thank you for your question

Here is a quick summary on your question:

Regarding IAS: yes you can use a separate IAS tenant for your new TDD tenant but you will have to order additional SAP tenant plan rather than creating it yourself inside S4H. See Get Your Tenant and https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/tenant-model-and-licensing for more details.

For IPS, the standard is to have one for your tests environment one Prod. You normally do not need to buy a new IPS as a standalone service because they seem not to be available any longer. See KBA 3405942 for more insights.

So, what i recommend for IPS is to, reuse your existing IPS test bundle tenant and add the new TDD S4H tenant as an additional target system inside your IPS tenant, instead of trying to get a new IPS tenant.

If you truly need a third IPS tenant, then you can send a request to SAP.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom logic for migrating for migrating information...
entry.content:
Dear @c_walid,

Badi code runs only if your enhancement is assigned to a routine number and that routine number is assigned in copy control for the relevant billing flow.

1. Open SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC)

2. Run Define Custom Routines for Data Transfer to Billing Documents (102865)

    • Create a Routine Number
    • Assign your Enhancement ID, your Custom Logic implementation of SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER to that routine number.

3. Assign the routine number to Copying Control for your proces:

    • Sales Order and Billing Document or
    • Delivery and Billing Document, depending on how you generate invoices

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4603118feda9495892abadbe8f8c3d14/a7a8635e08694ebdaa48620fa9c2f89c.html

I have recreated your requirements in my environment, below are the assumptions:

  • I created customfield (YY1_DADA) on BP

 

  • I created MyField (YY1_MyField) on Billing Document

 

  • In customfield on BP I put it in value below:

 

  • I used a Badi: SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER with code below:

 

"--- Mandatory step for all implementations:

MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc           TO bil_doc_res.

MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item      TO bil_doc_item_res.

MOVE-CORRESPONDING bil_doc_item_contr TO bil_doc_item_contr_res.

 

"--- Transfer BP custom field -> Billing Document custom field (Header)

DATA lv_bp    TYPE i_businesspartner-businesspartner.

DATA lv_dada  TYPE i_businesspartner-yy1_dada_bus.

 

lv_bp = |{ bil_doc-soldtoparty ALPHA = IN }|.

 

IF lv_bp IS NOT INITIAL AND bil_doc_res-yy1_myfield_bdh IS INITIAL.

 

  SELECT SINGLE yy1_dada_bus

    FROM i_businesspartner

    WHERE businesspartner = @lv_bp

    INTO @lv_dada.

 

  IF sy-subrc = 0 AND lv_dada IS NOT INITIAL.

    bil_doc_res-yy1_myfield_bdh = lv_dada.

  ENDIF.

 

ENDIF.

 

  • Badi transfer value from Master Data to Billing Document

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Billing indicator mapping configuration in sap JVA
entry.content:
Hello Kaustubh,

Below are some details which might be helpful to you.

Billing Indicator Mapping in SAP Joint Venture Accounting is a foundational configuration used to determine how financial postings are treated during Joint Interest Billing. Since standard FI and CO postings do not explicitly indicate whether a cost or revenue should be billed to joint venture partners, SAP uses this mapping to derive billing relevance based on predefined rules.

The configuration evaluates the posting source through object types such as G/L accounts, cost elements, and transaction types, along with defined account ranges and settlement contexts. Based on this evaluation, a billing indicator is assigned, which governs whether the item is included in billing, excluded, netted, or treated as overhead or revenue.

During JIB processing, the billing indicator drives extraction, netting, and partner billing behavior. Incorrect or incomplete mappings are a common root cause of billing discrepancies, such as costs not appearing in JIB or settlements being billed incorrectly. Following best practices and maintaining well-structured, documented mappings ensures accurate partner billing and compliance with joint venture agreements.

 

TopicExplanation
PurposeBilling Indicator Mapping determines whether FI/CO postings are billable, non-billable, nettable, overhead, revenue, or excluded during Joint Interest Billing (JIB).
Business NeedFI/CO documents do not inherently contain billing relevance; this mapping converts accounting attributes into JIB billing logic.
Configuration ObjectBilling Indicator Mapping
Transaction CodeGJVL
SPRO PathSAP IMG ‚Üí Financial Accounting ‚Üí Joint Venture Accounting ‚Üí Joint Interest Billing ‚Üí Define Billing Indicator Mapping
Object TypeIdentifies the source of posting such as G/L Account (GL), Cost Element (CE), or Transaction Type (TT).
Account / Cost Element RangeDefines the nature of cost or revenue and drives the assignment of billing indicators.
Transaction TypeDifferentiates primary postings from settlements or assessments and prevents incorrect billing of secondary costs.
Billing IndicatorThe derived output that controls JIB behavior (e.g., BILL, NBIL, NET, OH, REV, EXCL).
Indicator Derivation LogicDuring JIB extraction, SAP evaluates object type, account or cost element range, and transaction type to assign a billing indicator.
JIB Processing ImpactBilling indicator controls extraction, netting, partner billing, and partner statements.
FI/CO Posting RequirementsDocument must contain Joint Venture and Equity Group for JIB relevance.
ExampleCost Element 410000 (Drilling Cost) mapped with Object Type CE and Billing Indicator BILL results in partner billing.
Common IssuesMissing mappings, incorrect object type, broad account ranges, or missing transaction types for settlements.
Troubleshooting ApproachAnalyze FI document ‚Üí Identify account/cost element ‚Üí Verify transaction type ‚Üí Check GJVL mapping ‚Üí Confirm billing indicator.
Best PracticeSeparate primary and secondary cost elements, maintain transaction types for settlements, avoid broad ranges, and document billing rules.
Governance & ControlRegular review of mappings aligned with joint operating agreements reduces billing disputes and audit risks.

If you find my response helpful, share your feedback. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your support.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Can i set a cookie for sap websites in order to login...
entry.content:
We offer the Single Sign-On (SSO) with SAP Passports feature, which enables you to access a wide range of SAP websites without entering your S-user ID and password, while ensuring the secure transmission of your data.

Once you apply for an SAP Passport via SAP for Me, the SAP Trust Center will issue your digital SAP Passport. This credential serves as a secure link between your local computer access permissions and your SAP for Me access credentials. With this in place, you no longer need to enter your user ID and password when accessing designated SAP websites.

For further details, please refer to the SAP Knowledge Base Article:1296615 - How to apply for and install the SAP Passport browser certificate - SAP for Me

entry.title: Re: Printing 500 char field in smartform
entry.content:
I got the answer for that.

Just convert the Text node into Include text and pass the 'READ_TEXT' variables to Include Text and you will get the output. 

You don't need the extra program line for READ_TEXT FM to get the output. Include Text will get it automatically and also it will set the allignment along with that.

entry.title: A 60-Minute Regression Test Plan for Joule in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Purpose: This is a fast, repeatable regression you can run every release cycle in Preview and as a post-deployment sanity check in Production. It focuses on Joule behaviors that SAP documents as supported in SAP SuccessFactors (transactional, navigational, informational), and it keeps evidence lightweight so the result is defensible for release sign-off and audit conversations.

What this checklist covers

  • Joule launch + basic responsiveness (identity + enablement symptoms)
  • RBP-aligned outputs using SAP‚Äôs documented SuccessFactors prompts (employee profile, manager/direct reports)
  • High-signal modules beyond Core:
    • Time Management (example: leave balance)
    • Performance & Goals (example: open goal plan, show goals)
    • Recruiting (example: show pending approvals, open offer approvals)
    • Succession & Development (example: open Talent Search, show succession org chart)
    • Compensation / Rewards (example: compensation forms, award balance)
  • Minimum viable evidence (privacy-aware screenshots + test log)

Important SAP guardrails (read this first)

  • Use test / anonymized data: Avoid real employee identifiers in prompts. Keep prompts minimal and evidence redacted.
  • Interpret results through RBP: If a user cannot see something in the standard UI due to Role-Based Permissions (RBP), Joule outputs should not surface it either.

Prep (5 minutes)

Test users

User Role Why you need it

U2Manager (MSS) with direct reportsMain Joule regression user for manager scenarios
U3Employee (ESS only, no direct reports)Boundary checks (employee vs manager outputs)
U4Restricted user (excluded from Joule access)Negative test (Joule not visible / not accessible)

Evidence setup

  • Create a secure folder (SharePoint / Confluence / Jira attachment) for this release cycle‚Äôs evidence.
  • Have a simple redaction method ready (blur names/IDs if any appear in screenshots).

0‚Äì5 minutes: Smoke check (Joule availability)

Test 1 ‚Äî Joule launches and responds (U2)

  1. Log in as U2.
  2. Confirm the Joule entry point is visible (where enabled for your tenant/user).
  3. Open Joule and send: ‚ÄúHello‚Äù

Expected: Joule opens without error and returns a basic response.

If it fails (common root causes):

  • Tenant enablement / user assignment / eligibility
  • Identity setup and mapping prerequisites (IAS/BTP integration dependencies can present as ‚ÄúJoule doesn‚Äôt load‚Äù symptoms)

Evidence: Screenshot showing Joule opened + first response

Sample Screenshots

5‚Äì35 minutes: Core regression prompts (SAP-documented use cases)

Rule of thumb: Keep prompts clean. Use test identities. Avoid sensitive data. If the user does not have UI access, Joule should not surface the data.

A) Platform / Employee Profile (RBP-aligned)

Test 2 ‚Äî View hire date (U2)

Prompt: ‚ÄúWant to view my hire date.‚Äù

Expected: Returns the hire date if permitted; otherwise, does not expose it.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

Test 3 ‚Äî View job code (U2)

Prompt: ‚ÄúView my job code.‚Äù

Expected: Returns job code if permitted.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

Test 4 ‚Äî Direct reports boundary (U2 vs U3)

Prompt: ‚ÄúDisplay my direct reports.‚Äù

  • Run as U2 (Manager): should return direct reports.
  • Run as U3 (Employee): should return ‚Äúno direct reports‚Äù/no records.

Pass criteria: Different outputs consistent with roles.

Evidence: Two screenshots (U2 and U3)

Sample Screenshot

B) Time Management (Time Off / leave balance)

Test 5 ‚Äî View leave balance (U2)

Prompt: ‚ÄúHow many holidays do I have?‚Äù

Expected: Returns available leave balance (or an appropriate message if not configured/available).

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

C) Performance & Goals (high-signal manager workflows)

Test 6 ‚Äî Open goal plan (U2)

Prompt: ‚ÄúGo to my goal plan.‚Äù

Expected: Displays list of plans and helps to navigates or guides to goal plan (behavior depends on configuration and permissions).

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

Test 7 ‚Äî Show goals (U2)

Prompt: ‚ÄúShow my goals.‚Äù

Expected: Lists goals accessible to U2.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

D) Recruiting (approvals + recruiter/hiring manager actions)

Test 8 ‚Äî Pending approvals (U2 if applicable)

Prompt: ‚ÄúShow pending approval.‚Äù

Expected: Displays approvals if U2 has recruiting approval responsibilities; otherwise, returns an appropriate ‚Äúnone/no access‚Äù result.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

 

Test 9 ‚Äî Offer approval navigation (U2 if applicable)

Prompt: ‚ÄúI want to open offer approvals.‚Äù

Expected: Opens or guides to offer approvals if requests need your approval.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

E) Succession & Development (talent search + succession views)

Test 10 ‚Äî Open Talent Search (U2 / U1 depending on permissions)

Prompt: ‚ÄúGo to Talent Search.‚Äù

Expected: Navigates/guides to Talent Search if enabled and permitted.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

Test 11 ‚Äî Succession org chart (U2 if applicable)

Prompt: ‚ÄúShow succession org chart.‚Äù

Expected: Opens/guides to succession org chart if enabled and permitted.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

F) Compensation / Rewards (optional but valuable)

Test 12 ‚Äî Compensation forms (U2 as manager, if Compensation is live)

Prompt: ‚ÄúNeed to review compensation forms.‚Äù

Expected: Directs to form inbox / relevant page if configured and permitted.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

Test 13 ‚Äî Award balance (U3 as employee, if Rewards & Recognition is live)

Prompt: ‚ÄúView my reward balance.‚Äù

Expected: Directs to rewards balance page if configured and permitted.

Evidence: Screenshot of prompt + response

Sample Screenshot

35‚Äì45 minutes: Negative access test

Test 14 ‚Äî Restricted user (U4) cannot access Joule

  1. Log in as U4 (role excluded from Joule access).
  2. Confirm Joule is not visible/accessible.

Expected: Joule is not available to U4 (or access is denied per your configuration).

Evidence: Screenshot showing U4 context and Joule not available

45‚Äì60 minutes: Evidence log (audit-ready, privacy-aware)

Minimum viable evidence

  • Record the tenant (Preview/Production), date, release wave, tester
  • Mark each test Pass/Fail and store a screenshot link
  • Confirm screenshots are redacted (no real names/IDs) before archiving

Copy/paste test log template

===== JOULE REGRESSION LOG (SAP SUCCESSFACTORS) =====
Tenant: [ ] Preview  [ ] Production
Release Cycle: ___________________________
Test Date (YYYY-MM-DD): __________________
Tester: __________________________________

Test # | User | Module Area              | Result      | Evidence Link | Notes
-------|------|--------------------------|-------------|---------------|-----------------------------
1      | U2   | Launch / Smoke           | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Joule opens + responds
2      | U2   | Employee Profile         | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Hire date
3      | U2   | Employee Profile         | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Job code
4      | U2/U3| Boundary (Direct reports)| Pass / Fail | [link]        | Manager vs employee
5      | U2   | Time Management          | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Leave balance
6      | U2   | Performance & Goals      | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Go to goal plan
7      | U2   | Performance & Goals      | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Show goals
8      | U2   | Recruiting (if applicable)| Pass / Fail| [link]        | Pending approvals
9      | U2   | Recruiting (if applicable)| Pass / Fail| [link]        | Offer approvals
10     | U2   | Succession & Development | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Talent Search
11     | U2   | Succession & Development | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Succession org chart
12     | U2   | Compensation (optional)  | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Compensation forms
13     | U3   | Rewards (optional)       | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Award balance
14     | U4   | Negative access          | Pass / Fail | [link]        | Joule not accessible

PRIVACY CHECK:
[ ] Prompts used test/anonymized data only
[ ] Screenshots reviewed and redacted where needed
[ ] Evidence stored in restricted-access location

Pass/Fail interpretation (what to do next)

Blockers (do not ignore)

  • Any data exposure: Joule surfaces employee information that the user cannot access in the standard UI (treat as critical).
  • Launch failures: Joule can‚Äôt open/respond for an intended role in Preview/Production.
  • Role boundary failures: U3 (employee) receives manager-only content (direct reports/org data).

Common non-blockers (document + monitor)

  • Navigation guidance differs by tenant configuration or role design.
  • Some module tests are ‚ÄúNot Applicable‚Äù if the module isn‚Äôt deployed or the user has no responsibility in that area.

Conclusion

This checklist is intentionally lean. It doesn‚Äôt try to test every Joule intent, it targets the highest blast-radius issues: launch readiness, RBP-aligned outputs, and a handful of SAP-documented module scenarios that catch real-world breakpoints quickly. Run it in Preview every release cycle, repeat it after Production deployment, and you‚Äôll spot most high-impact issues early with minimal effort.

entry.title: üáÆüáπ Joule Studio: Create Skills and Agents to Extend Joule (Milan, Italy)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for Joule Studio, the new tool in SAP Build that lets you create extensions to Joule so users can use SAP's digital assistant in their custom workflows.

The CodeJam is intended to introduce you to the Joule Studio tool, so you can create your own:

  • Skills, which let you create predefined execution flows, triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot
  • Agents, which lets you define complex scenarios that the agent can execute by iteratively reasoning and interacting with their environment to achieve a goal, using a selected LLM, and triggered by a user's prompt inside the Joule chatbot

The session will include a short, simple introduction to the SAP AI tools and some basic concepts needed for working with Joule Studio ‚Äì such as AI Core, document grounding, embeddings, and what after all is an LLM.

Currently, much of the session is based on the TechEd hands-on tutorials for DT160.

Prerequisites

  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have, to have the instructions on a separate screen.

Location and Date 

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, February 3, 2026 from 09:30 - 16:00 local time in Milan, Italy (CET). The language of the event and the content will be English.

Event Address: Viale Francesco Restelli, 5, 20124, Milan, Italy

  • The event is kindly being hosted by SYscons ‚Äì THANK YOU!
  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocate @Dan_Wroblewski.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 25 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About 2 weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance and will receive further instructions.

entry.title: How to track stock by pack size (5/25/50kg) with one material number?
entry.content:
Hi all,

I have a case where one product (example: Cement) is physically stored and sold in different pack sizes: 5kg, 25kg, and 50kg bags.

Business want one material number only.

  • In reality, each pack size can have a different cost, so I handled that using split valuation (different valuation types per pack size).

  • But I‚Äôm wondering: if the cost is the same (so no need for split valuation), would it make sense to manage the different pack sizes using Handling Units (HU) in WMS ?

I tried HU management, but it looks like each individual bag becomes an HU, which feels unrealistic (you could end up with millions of HUs).

So my questions are:

  1. If cost is the same, what‚Äôs the best practice to represent the different pack sizes while still keeping one material?

  2. Is HU management meant for this scenario, or is it more for pallets/cartons only (and bags should be handled differently)?

Best regards,
Faisal

entry.title: Re: Unable to Use ZCDS or Any Standard CDS View in AMDP T...
entry.content:
Dear @akash_dutta,

Answer to Q1:

  • You can use a CDS view in AMDP only if that CDS view and its dependencies is released for Contract C4
  • If it‚Äôs only C1 released like in your screenshot, AMDP will not allow it

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-development-tools-user-guide/use-in-abap-managed-database-procedures-c4

https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_cp_index_htm/CLOUD/en-US/ABENAMDP.html

Answer to Q2:

  • For your own custom CDS (Z*) you must add release contract C4 in ADT->Properties->API State then activate
  • For SAP standard CDS (I*) you cannot change their contracts in Public Cloud. Only SAP can release them

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-development-tools-user-guide/setting-api-release-state

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3504675

Answer to Q3:

  • There is no supported bypass of the release-contract check in Public Cloud
  • Practical options are:
    1. Use a CDS view that is already released for C4 or a released API alternative
    2. Avoid AMDP and implement logic in ABAP/Open SQL or a RAP Query Provider / Custom Entity
    3. Request SAP to release the needed standard object if the blocker is an I_* dependency

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-cloud/public-released-apis

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Technical Insight: Resolving Update Terminations (SM13) due to NRIV Inconsistency in UAT.
entry.content:
Technical Insight: Resolving Update Terminations due to NRIV Inconsistency in UAT

Date: January 2026

Author: Er. Pratik Das (B.Tech, Mechanical Engineering | SAP Functional Consultant)

Target Audience: SAP MM Consultants, Support Leads, and Basis Teams

  1. Overview

In a recent User Acceptance Testing (UAT) cycle, we encountered a persistent "Express Document: Update was Terminated" error during Purchase Order generation via transaction ME21N. While this error is often associated with custom logic, this specific case highlighted the critical importance of post-copy configuration steps‚Äîspecifically regarding Number Range (NRIV) synchronization.

  1. The Problem Statement

The user could successfully validate the Purchase Order using the "Check" button with no red messages. However, upon clicking Save, the system triggered the "Express Document" popup.

For a functional consultant, the immediate challenge here is a "ghost" document: the system identifies a PO number, but the record is never committed to the database tables (EKKO/EKPO), leaving no trace of the document in the system.

  1. Diagnostic Steps: Finding the Smoking Gun

To move beyond the generic error message, we followed the standard SAP troubleshooting protocol:

  • Transaction SM13 (Update Oversight): The update record for function module ME_UPDATE_DOCUMENT showed a status of Error.
  • Transaction ST22 (ABAP Dump Analysis): A corresponding short dump was found.

The Technical Reality: The error info confirmed the following runtime error:

DBSQL_DUPLICATE_KEY_ERROR

This translates to a "Duplicate Key" conflict at the database level. The system is attempting to insert a new row into the header table (EKKO), but the Purchasing Document number it has generated is already assigned to an existing record in the database.

 

  1. Root Cause: Why this happens in UAT

This is a classic post-refresh issue. When a UAT environment is refreshed from Production, the transactional data (the POs) is copied, but the Number Range Status (NR Status) may not have been synchronized correctly during the post-copy automation (PCA) steps.

If the database contains POs up to number 4500001000, but the Number Range status (table NRIV) is still sitting at 4500000800, the system will try to "re-use" numbers that already exist, leading to an immediate database conflict.

  1. Resolution Strategy: Synchronizing OMH7

To resolve this, the Number Range status must be manually aligned with the highest existing document number in the current client.

  1. Identify the Highest Consumed Number: * Go to SE16N and check table EKKO.
    • Sort the EBELN (Purchasing Document) column in descending order to find the latest number.
  2. Access Number Range Maintenance: * Navigate to OMH7 (or SNRO for object EF_BELEG).
  3. Update Interval Status: * Locate the interval assigned to your PO Document Type.
    • Update the "NR Status" field to match the highest number found in Step 1.
  4. Verification: * Clear the local buffer and re-test ME21N. The system will now fetch the next available unique integer.
  1. Conclusion

The "Express Document" error in UAT is a reminder that functional configuration is only half the battle; data consistency across the landscape is equally vital. Before assuming there is a system bug or a code error, always check SM13. If you see a Duplicate Key error, your solution lies in the Number Range status.

entry.title: API-Based Bank Integration for SAP BCM ‚Äì Seeking Best Practices and Lessons Learned
entry.content:
We are planning to embark on a new project focused on integrating with banks via APIs. Currently, we use pain.001 messages to send payment instructions to the bank and transmit via SFTP and receive pain.002 responses, which we process to update BCM statuses.

For this new approach, we do not intend to use any SAP middleware components such as MBC or the Digital Payments Add-On. Instead, we aim to consume the bank‚Äôs existing APIs directly as there will be no APIs on our side. Also, we would like to continue using the BCM monitor but not sure how this will be updated using APIs. We are still using the S4HANA On-Premise version.

Questions for the Community

  • Has anyone implemented a similar API-based integration with banks?
  • How did you approach the implementation and testing with the bank?
  • Does the bank proactively notify you when they change or update their APIs?
  • How feasible is this scenario compared to traditional file-based integration or when using some middleware?

    Additional Considerations

    • Security: How do you manage authentication (OAuth, certificates, token refresh) and ensure secure data transmission?
    • Error Handling: What strategies do you use for retries, timeouts, and reconciliation if API calls fail or responses are delayed?
    • Monitoring: How do you track API performance and maintain an audit trail for compliance? Do you integrate with SAP BCM monitoring or build a custom dashboard?
    • Version Management: How do you handle API version changes and backward compatibility?
    • Performance: Are there latency issues compared to file-based pain.002 processing?

      Looking forward to your responses.

      Regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Unable to open CDS Graphical modeler in BAS (Trial) a...
entry.content:
Hi everyone,
I found that the issue occurs because the Network tab shows a 404 error ‚Äî the following SAPUI5 resource path cannot be found:

 
https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/1.108.34/resources/sap-ui-core.js
Because this resource fails to load, the UI5 bootstrap never initializes, which results in the error:

 

ReferenceError: sap is not defined

üîßWorkaround

I was able to resolve this by redirecting the request to a valid SAPUI5 resource path using a Chrome extension.

Environment

  • OS: Windows (Note: Please verify and check according to your browser if using different needs)

  • Browser: Google Chrome

Chrome Extension (Redirect Tool)
Requestly ‚Äì HTTP Interceptor
https://chromewebstore.google.com/detail/requestly-supercharge-you/mdnleldcmiljblolnjhpnblkcekpdkpa

Step 1: Click New Rule HTTP Interceptor 

Step 2: Then make a Redirect Request :-

Step 3: Make a regex check rule as follows, and save the rule: 

Copy paste: the following: 
If request:         /^https://sapui5\.hana\.ondemand\.com/1\.108\.34/(.*)$/
Redirects to:    https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/1.108.46/$1

 

Once you‚Äôve filled in the above details, click Save Rule, then reload SAP Business Application Studio and reopen SCHEMA.cds using the CDS Graphical Data Modeler.

The modeler should now load correctly and you‚Äôre all set to go!!!

Error Message: You can't create partner connections for Risk Providers in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration anymore. To set up connections for Risk Providers, subscribe to SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace where you can create new connections for them.

Meanwhile, we can't see any option under "Service"  filed which has been configured by carrier. And we don't know why the specified carrier was identified as "Risk Providers" .

entry.title: Re: How to make ASN field as mandatory in /SCWN/GR screen in Decentralized EWM
entry.content: In Decentralized EWM, the ASN field in the /SCWN/GR screen is optional by default, but you can make it mandatory either through screen field control customizing in SPRO or by implementing a validation BAdI (such as /SCWM/EX_GR_CHECK) to raise an error if the field is empty. If customizing doesn‚Äôt offer the option, the BAdI approach is the reliable way to enforce it.

entry.title: Unlocking the NPP: PayID
entry.content:
Welcome to the third installment of the Blog series on the New Payments Platform (‚ÄúNPP‚Äù) in Australia.

The series is planned as:

  1. Unlocking the NPP: SAP Capabilities for Faster, Smarter Payments
  2. Unlocking the NPP: Payments overview
  3. Unlocking the NPP: PayID
  4. Unlocking the NPP: PayTo

 

PayID (OSKO)

PayID can be used as an alternative to specifying a Payee‚Äôs Bank Account and BSB details in an online Payment transaction or file. The PayID is chosen by the Payee and can be a mobile number, email address, ABN, or Organisation Identifier. PayID is also referred to as Osko, particularly in the context of Personal Banking.

The initial creation of the PayID is managed directly by the Payee with their Bank, typically through their online banking portal. The Bank will advise their customer (the Payee) which PayID types are available and will validate that the chosen PayID is not already in use, as well as checking it is in the required format. The central registry of PayIDs is part of the NPP infrastructure delivered by Australian Payments Plus (APP), with Banks able to query and update details. Once a PayID is created, the owner can change Banks and just update their existing PayID. 

The main benefits of using PayID in SAP are:

  • You don‚Äôt need to request or store Bank Account or BSB details in SAP, which could be regarded as sensitive information similar to Credit Card numbers. Individuals may be reluctant to divulge these as use of PayID / OSKO gains wider usage and security concerns increase.
  • The Payer no longer needs to update Payee Bank details in SAP if the Payee moves Banks or changes Bank Account details.

It is possible for a Payee to have more than one PayID and we‚Äôll describe how this can be handled below.

 

PayID in pain.001 format

APP has produced the document For guidance on using NPP payment initiation messages which contains details on the expected mapping of the PayID (or ‚ÄúProxy‚Äù) fields in the pain.001 file. The document refers to version 011 and describes these fields for PayID for outgoing payments:

  • Type - /CstmrCdtTrfInitn/PmtInf/CdtTrfTxI nf/CdtrAcct/Prxy/Tp/Prtry
  • Value - /CstmrCdtTrfInitn/PmtInf/CdtTrfTxI nf/CdtrAcct/Prxy/Id

You should be aware that these Proxy fields were only added to the ISO20021 pain.001 format in version 009. As described in the previous Blog, SAP standard content refers to version 006 so does not contain these Proxy fields. Similarly where Banks use version 003, these latest standard Proxy fields will not be available and they may direct usage of alternate fields. This can be managed through the standard DMEE configuration activities.

 

PayID in SAP

There are a couple of options for the management of PayID depending on your SAP system:

  • Bank Account Alias
    • Standard function for handling Account Proxy / PayID
    • Available for On Premise / Private Cloud from S/4HANA 2021 FPS01
    • Available in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Standard or Custom fields on Business Partner
    • For example if the Supplier uses a Phone number as their PayID, you could use standard fields from the Business Partner Communication data such as Telephone, Telex or Fax. However where these are already populated with different values, it may be necessary to use other fields or create your own.
    • Ensure you are familiar with the mapping process from Business Partner to standard Payment Structures (FPAYP, FPAYH and FPAYH). Leveraging the standard mapping will make it possible to define the source for PayID within the Payment Format without requiring additional coding.

Source of Information for Field in structures FPAYH-FPAYHX-FPAYP

  • Where coding is required, BAdI FBL_EVENT_06 enables population of ZREF01-ZREF10 fields which can then be mapped to the DMEE fields.

 

Bank Account Alias

We‚Äôll take a look at the configuration and master data settings required to work with the Bank Account Alias using standard SAP functionality.

SSCUI for Public Cloud

IMG for On Premise and Private Cloud

 

Alias Types

  • Alias Type can be created to align to the standard NPP values or any Bank Specific values.
  • Validation determines how the field contents will be checked:
    • Tax number categories references the settings in
      • SSCUI 102415 - Maintain Tax Number Categories
      • SPRO Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Tax Numbers ‚Üí Define Tax Number Categories
      • Rule AU0 checks ‚ÄúVAT Reg.No. must have the length 11 or 14‚Äù
    • Email, Phone number and Organisation use Regular Expressions (code) to validate the length and format of the entries.
    • The NPP mapping guidance document (link above) includes sample RegEx code which can be pasted into each Validation Rule but you can easily create your own using SAP Joule for Consultants or other GenAI tools. Note that the NPP will accept any phone number but you may wish to limit to AU formats for landlines and mobiles (as shown in the above example).

 

Payment System configuration links the Alias Types to the Country.

 

The Bank Account Alias also needs a dedicated ‚ÄúInternal Bank‚Äù - a single entry is sufficient for country AU.

Manage Banks - Master Data F6437

 

Business Partner

The Bank Account Alias is maintained under Payment Transactions along with Bank Accounts. The above example shows the Alias is maintained with default ID ‚Äú0001‚Äù which is fine if there is only one entry in the table. We'll see below how to handle BSB / Bank Account and / or additional PaYID for a Business Partner. 

 

The Bank Account Alias details are automatically mapped to the below fields in FFPAYH and from there can be mapped in DMEEX to the required pain.001 nodes.

 

PayID Validation

Whilst PayID has potential benefits, one of the issues to consider is how to ensure the PayID details entered on the Business Partner are correct. The Validation configuration settings will check the format, but will not ensure the actual value is correct and errors are possible. The PayID will be validated for existence by the Bank prior to forwarding the payment file to the NPP, however Customers will be responsible for ensuring the details are correct.

If you process a payment with a PayID through an Online Banking portal, you can view additional details on who the PayID is registered to. This provides additional confidence the payment will reach the desired Payee. This manual check could be used for low volume usage of PayID.

Unfortunately at this stage NPP does not provide the capability to perform automated checks as part of Master Data maintenance or prior to sending the Payment File to SAP or other Digital Service Providers.  The NPP ‚ÄúConfirmation of Payee‚Äù service only relates to payments made with BSB and Bank Account.

SAP Customers are recommended to discuss potential solutions with their Banks or to ensure Payees have verified the captured PayID information prior to using in Payment Files.

 

Working with PayID

Business Partner with Bank details and two PayIDs. The field "ID" on the BP Bank Details view is the same as the Partner Bank Type field on an Invoice Document header. The ID values will default to 0001, 0002 etc but can be populated with specific values such as PAY1, PAY2 etc at time of initial creation.

The system will follow the standard sequence for determination of Bank details in the payment run:

  1. Partner Bank Type (ID) in the Invoice document, either from manual entry or substitution. In S/4HANA Public Cloud this could be configuration or BADI.
  2. Partner Bank Type (ID) BTE 1810 (Private Cloud and On Premise only)
  3. Partner Bank Type (ID) with lowest ranking from Blank, then 0001 to ZZZZ. In the above example the Bank Key / Account would continue to be used as the default value of 0001 would be selected first.

Refer KBA 2983466 - Incorrect Partner Bank Type (BVTYP) is selected by Automatic Payment Program for further details.

 

You may also consider whether to create a new Payment Method for PayID payments as the configuration allows setting Bank Account Alias as mandatory on Business Partner. It also provides an easy way to separate Payment Runs.

SAP Help ‚Äì Bank Account Alias

SAP Help ‚Äì Business Partner ‚Äì Bank Account Alias

 

PayID for incoming payments

The process of setting up a PayID for incoming payments is managed directly with the Bank. You may create a custom field on the Bank Account master data which can be included on outgoing invoices instead of the BSB and Bank Account details or just manage through Standard Texts. Your customers pay using the PayID but otherwise the Bank Statements and reconciliation process remain unchanged.

entry.title: Detecting CDS View 2nd Level Dependencies on Custom Fields in SAP Transport Cross Reference Check
entry.content:
Introduction

When transporting custom CDS views, dependency management becomes critical, especially if CDS views rely on custom fields added via appends to SAP standard tables. SAP Note [2964512] documents a limitation: the standard cross reference check (as run in transaction `/SDF/TRCHECK` or Change Request Management) does not detect ‚Äú2nd level‚Äù dependencies‚Äîcases where your CDS view depends on fields from a *custom append* to a standard table. This can cause runtime errors after transport if the append is missing in the target system.

This blog describes how I worked around this by customizing the check logic so it explicitly includes Z-fields in CDS dependencies, letting you catch these hidden dependencies before you move your transports.

The Problem

Imagine you‚Äôre transporting a custom CDS view that selects fields from a SAP standard table. The table itself has been extended by a custom append containing several Z* fields. If the CDS view uses one of these Z-fields and the append is not present in the target system, the import will fail with a runtime dump. Unfortunately, the standard cross reference check does not flag these second-level dependencies, so you don‚Äôt know about the missing append until it‚Äôs too late.

Custom Solution Overview

To address this limitation, I followed these steps:

1. Copied the Standard Report and Includes
I made a custom copy of `/SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK` and all its includes:

| Standard | Custom |
|------------------|----------------------|
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK | ZCMO_TR_CHECK |
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_FORMS | ZCMO_TR_CHECK_FORMS |
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_INC1 | ZCMO_TR_CHECK_INC1 |
| /SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_INC2 | ZCMO_TR_CHECK_INC2 |
| /SDF/_TR_CHECK_GET_SID_RFCF01 | ZTR_CHECK_GET_SID_RFCF01 |

 

2. Used a Custom Copy of the Dependency Analyzer FM
In the custom include (formerly `/SDF/CMO_TR_CHECK_FORMS` at line 1128), I replaced the standard call:

CALL FUNCTION '/SDF/TEAP_ENVI_ANA'.
with
CALL FUNCTION 'ZTEAP_ENVI_ANA'.

3. Enhanced the FM to Detect Z-fields in Appends
Inside the custom FM (`ZTEAP_ENVI_ANA`), after the section:
* Delete MSAG
DELETE lt_objs_ref_tab WHERE ref_obj_type = 'MSAG'.

I added logic to explicitly look for Z-fields in the tables referenced by the CDS view. This augments the standard cross-reference logic to handle this otherwise missed scenario.


    TYPES : BEGIN OF ty_ref_obj,
              obj_name TYPE ddstrucobjname,
            END OF ty_ref_obj.


    TYPES : BEGIN OF ty_tadir,
              rollname TYPE sobj_name,
            END OF ty_tadir.

    DATA : lt_ref_obj TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_ref_obj.
    DATA : lt_tadir_tmp TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_tadir.

    DATA(lt_tmp) = lt_objs_ref_tab.

    SORT lt_tmp BY obj_name.
    DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_tmp COMPARING obj_name.
    DELETE lt_tmp WHERE ref_obj_type <> 'TABL'.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING lt_tmp TO lt_ref_obj.

    DATA lt_dd03l TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF dd03l.
    DATA lt_tadir_new TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF tadir.
    DATA lt_dd03nd TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF dd03nd.

    SELECT *
      FROM dd03nd
      INTO TABLE lt_dd03nd
      FOR ALL ENTRIES IN lt_ref_obj
      WHERE strucobjn = lt_ref_obj-obj_name
      AND rollname  LIKE 'Z%'.

    SORT lt_dd03nd BY strucobjn rollname.
    DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_dd03nd COMPARING strucobjn rollname.

    MOVE-CORRESPONDING lt_dd03nd TO lt_tadir_tmp.

    SELECT *
      FROM tadir
      INTO TABLE lt_tadir_new
      FOR ALL ENTRIES IN lt_tadir_tmp
      WHERE obj_name = lt_tadir_tmp-rollname.

    DATA(lt_objs_ref_tab_new) = lt_tmp.
    CLEAR lt_objs_ref_tab_new.
    SORT lt_tmp BY obj_name ref_obj_name.
    LOOP AT lt_tmp INTO DATA(wa_ref).
      LOOP AT lt_dd03nd INTO DATA(wa_dd03nd) WHERE strucobjn = wa_ref-obj_name.
        wa_ref-ref_obj_name = wa_dd03nd-rollname.
        LOOP AT lt_tadir_new INTO DATA(wa_tadir) WHERE obj_name = wa_dd03nd-rollname.
          wa_ref-ref_pgmid = wa_tadir-pgmid.
          wa_ref-ref_obj_type = wa_tadir-object.
          APPEND wa_ref TO lt_objs_ref_tab_new.
          CLEAR wa_tadir.
        ENDLOOP.
        CLEAR wa_dd03nd.
      ENDLOOP.
      CLEAR wa_ref.
    ENDLOOP.


    APPEND LINES OF lt_objs_ref_tab_new TO lt_objs_ref_tab.

 

Outcome & Benefits

With this logic in place, running your custom version of the cross reference check will now also surface missing custom Z-fields referenced by CDS views. This eliminates false negatives and gives you a complete picture of technical dependencies, meaning you can catch potential short dumps or import errors *before* they occur in production.

Conclusion

If you‚Äôre dealing with custom extensions to SAP standard tables and building CDS views on top of those, incorporating this enhancement into your transport process can help you proactively spot and resolve these tricky second-level dependencies. This saves both time and effort‚Äîand avoids unexpected surprises during system imports.

Have you implemented other tricks or enhancements around dependency checks and transports? Let me know in the comments!

entry.title: SAP FI-CA Return Processing: Implementing Foreign Exchange (FX) Postings
entry.content:
1. Introduction 

In this article I explain how you can implement automatic posting of foreign exchange (FX) differences in return processing using events 0261 and 0290 in SAP S/4HANA BRIM FI-CA. In the past, this was often a pain point in many SAP implementations since reconciling FX differences from return processing required additional manual effort and customer-specific handling of FX differences was not previously enabled in FI-CA Return process.

Before SAP introduced changes in the return process, FX differences were managed through workaround solutions, which were often manual and led to user errors which complicated the situation for finance teams responsible for accurate accounting.

 

2. Technical Implementation

In the following text, I will explain how to implement the solution in the latest version of S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 BRIM FI-CA.  If you are using earlier product versions, check that all relevant SAP Notes are applied in your installation: 2931294, 2932255, 2898368, 2878681, 2948561. 

 

This article is for informational purposes only. Its purpose is to provide overall guidance and outline a possible technical implementation approach.

 

2. 1 Scenario

US based company selling services in Canada through its web portal. Customer in Canada ordered several services and pays using a credit card denominated in CAD. Although the invoice is displayed to the customer in CAD, the transactions in the system are recorded USD.

Assuming a standard BRIM data flow, the invoice with total amount of USD 1000 and payment were processed to SAP FI-CA through BIT processing in Convergent Invoicing. Later, the credit card provider reverses the payment and reports a returned amount of USD 998. Payment reversal will be posted to customer account trough FI-CA Return Lot process, reinstating the receivable to USD 1000, the difference of USD 2 between the original invoice and the returned payment should be recognised as FX Loss in financial reporting.

 

2.2  Implementation

Event 0261 - Activate FX Calculation   

In this event you check if the returned amount is different than original payment amount and if so, activate FX calculation. This can be done by comparing return amount in I_DFKKRP-BETRW and original payment amount in I_BETRE. In our example, I_DFKKRP-BETRW = 998 and I_BETRE = 1000.

If there is a difference, pass ‚ÄúX‚Äù into output parameter E_ACTIVATE to activate FX calculation in the event 0290.

The next part is customer specific and requires knowing exact business requirements. In principle, the FX calculation should only be activated if the difference is truly originating from the FX difference. To implement the additional condition, you can access all return lot data in I_DFKKRP, and tailor the logic to accommodate specific customer scenarios, for instance, check the original payment method, credit card data, return reason etc. to determine if the FX posting is required.

As a starting point, review the sample logic in FKK_SAMPLE_0261 and enhance the logic as required.

Figure 1 Sample coding in Event 0261

 

Event 0290 - Add FX GL Line in

In this event you create new GL line for FX difference to ensure that the return posting remains balanced on credit/debit side. New FX line should be added to the last line in table structure T_FKKOPK.

From a sequence perspective, first call FM FKK_RLS_FIND_CURRENT_DATA to calculate the FX difference amount and then add new GL line to the Return Document to balance the posting (refer to the sample code in Figure 3).

 

How to determine G/L Account?

Standard derives the FX Gain/Loss General Ledger account from Posting Area 0070 (Exchange Rate Differences). However, if the configuration of Posting Area is not sufficient to meet the customer requirements, you can implement custom logic in event 0290 to derive the appropriate FX loss or gain G/L accounts. In this case in addition to Event 0290, you must also implement Event 0291 to fetch and pass the correct G/L account to the FX GL Line.  

 

How to determine CO Account Assignment?

You can maintain Account Assignment for FX line in SPRO:

Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable ‚Üí Basic Functions ‚Üí Postings and Documents ‚Üí Document ‚Üí Define Account Assignments for Automatic Postings ‚Üí Define CO Account Assignment Keys.

 Make sure that CO Account Assignment key is maintained as ‚ÄúRLFX‚Äù.

Figure 2 SPRO: Define CO Account Assignment Keys

 

Alternatively, you can use event 290 to dynamically determine Acc. Assignment, for instance, from the original invoice and pass the values to FX GL Line (T_FKKOPK).

As a starting point, review sample code in FKK_SAMPLE_0290FX and adjust the logic to accommodate customer requirements.

Figure 3 Sample coding in event 0290 (Add FX G/L Line)

 

2.3 Accounting View

Using our original example, the return posting with the FX difference would look like this:

  • Invoice posting of USD 1000
  • Receivable & Payment Clearing USD 1000
  • Return Posting USD 998:
    • 3A) Amount returned by Credit Card Provider
    • 3B) FX Difference Loss
    • 3C) Customer Invoice reinstated in full amount

Figure 4 Return - Accounting View

 

3. Conclusion 

By implementing FI-CA Events 0261 and 0290, FX differences in return processing can be handled automatically. Key benefit of the solution is that the manual workarounds and extra reconciliation efforts are no longer required as FX gains and losses are correctly posted in the respective Gain/Loss General Ledger accounts. Overall, it simplifies accounting process and reduces manual operational effort in SAP S/4HANA BRIM FI-CA.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Time Tracking Integration Guide
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Sending Attendance Data to SuccessFactors
  • Understanding Timesheet Structure
  • The External Time Data Approach
  • Cross-Midnight Attendance - Date and Time Field Rules
  • Deleting Attendance in SuccessFactors
  • Sending Absence Data from SuccessFactors
  • Best Practices Summary

Introduction

Important Note of the author : Just because an API exists doesn't mean you should integrate with it. üôÇ Always use common sense, and if there's no documentation for your specific scenario, there's probably a good reason.

This guide shares knowledge I gained from integrating SuccessFactors Time Tracking with third-party systems. While this is considered an edge case, the lack of available documentation made me document my findings to help others avoid similar struggles.

Sending Attendance Data to SuccessFactors

Understanding Timesheet Structure

Attendance is recorded in the SuccessFactors timesheet with the following characteristics:

Every entry is logged:

Every change generates a new timesheet that replaces (and references) the old one. This creates an excellent audit trail within SuccessFactors. However, this complexity is why sending attendance data from SuccessFactors Time Sheet to other applications is a bit more difficult

The External Time Data Approach

You cannot directly generate timesheet entries from external systems. If you want to send attendances to the SuccessFactors Timesheet from a third-party system or from a terminal, the process works as follows.

  • POST an "External Time Data" record to SuccessFactors
  • The record is saved in the system
  • An import job processes the data (can be instant or scheduled - see SAP KB Article 2854180)
  • Either the data appears as an Employee Time Sheet Entry in the employee's timesheet or the validation error of the unimported external time data record appears in the time sheet as an admin alert

Posting Attendance to SuccessFactors

API Endpoint: POST "apiserverofyourdatacenter" + ExternalTimeData"

Request Body Example:

{

   "externalCode": "4545455",

   "startDate": "/Date(1759622400000)/",

   "userIdNav": {

      "__metadata": { "uri": "User('ABC')" }

   },

   "startTime": "PT3H0M0S",

   "endTime": "PT15H0M0S",

   "timeType": "1234"

}

And you will be able to create an external time data entity:

 

Important Validation Behavior

Critical: A successful API response does not guarantee successful timesheet entry.

Here's why:

You receive a positive HTTP response when the external time data record is created. The import job runs and applies timesheet validations.If validation fails (e.g., duplicate booking), the status changes from "New" to "Error". The integration has already received a positive response.

Error Detection Methods

Since the API response doesn't reflect validation errors, you must use:

  • Admin alerts for timesheet import failures
  • End-user notifications showing validation errors on their timesheet

Cross-Midnight Attendance - Date and Time Field Rules

The External Time Data entity has specific requirements for handling attendance that spans across calendar days:

Scenario

startDate

startTime

endDate

endTime

Same day attendance

Required

Required

Must NOT be provided

Required

Cross-midnight attendance

Required

Required

Required

Required

 

Key Principle I followed during the implementation  of the integration:

Provide endDate only if: startDate ‚â† endDate

Omit endDate if: the attendance ends on the same calendar day

Deleting Attendance in SuccessFactors

The Challenge: Since you cannot directly modify the timesheet, deleting attendance requires updating the External Time Data record with a deletion flag.

For the deletion process is used a PUT request.

API Endpoint: PUT  "apiserverofyourdatacenter + ExternalTimeData ('recordIdyouwanttodelete')"

Request Body Example:

{

    "externalCode": "recordIdyouwanttodelete",

    "userIdNav": {

        "__metadata": {

            "uri": "User('ABC')"

        }

    },

    "startDate": "/Date(1772082000000)/",

    "startTime": "PT06H00M00S",

    "endTime": "PT10H00M00S",

    "timeType": "123",

    "correctionScenario": "TIME_SHEET_AND_EXTERNAL_SYSTEM",

    "status": "NEW",

    "deleteExternalTime": true

}

Now the external time data record is updated, and the import job is triggered.

The import job reads the deleteExternalTime flag and the entry is deleted from the timesheet.

 

Sending Absence Data from SuccessFactors

While integrating attendance is a bit more complex, sending absences to another system is pretty straight forward. SuccessFactors provides an intelligent service that enables near-real-time absence data transmission to third-party applications.

Integration Architecture

The integration uses the following components:

  • Base Object: EmployeeTime
  • Business Rule: Filters when to trigger the intelligent service
  • Intelligent Service: "Employee Central: Employee Time Off"
  • Integration Center Job: Sends data to the third-party REST endpoint

 

Implementation Steps

Step 1: Configure Business Rule

Define a business rule on the EmployeeTime object to filter trigger conditions. In this example Rule only workflow-approved or auto-approved or cancelled absences are triggering the intelligent service.

Step 2: Set Up Intelligent Service

Use the "Employee Central: Employee Time Off" intelligent service.

Optional: The flow rule provides you with an additional possibility to filter.

I use the flows on Timing ‚Äúwhen event is published‚Äù to get the near realtime data transfer.

Step 3: Build Integration Center Job

Configure the job to be triggered by the intelligent service. The job can send:

  • The entire EmployeeTime record as a body
  • Or like in my case just the uuid of the record that has been changed. This largely depends on your entire integration architecture and there are reasons for both scenarios.

The data is transmitted to the REST endpoint of your third-party application.

Best Practices Summary

  • Always validate that your use case is supported before integrating
  • Implement proper error handling for async validation failures
  • Use admin alerts to monitor import job failures
  • Timestamps and time formats are just weird in SuccessFactors -  I guess we have to live with that üôÑ
  • Follow date/time rules carefully for cross-midnight scenarios.
  • Use the intelligent service for real-time absence data transmission
  • Test thoroughly in a sandbox environment before production deployment

entry.title: Re: Contribution Margin Forecast with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Thank you for this blog post.

Can I just validate my understanding and generalise on what it means for future-proof recommended architecture of planning solutions. I tried to read a little bit between the lines and deduced the following:

1. Provided now tight integration of SAC with SAP Datasphere / BDC with their calculation power, the recommendation for planning calculations is to start shifting balance towards using Datasphere calculation views vs SAC Data Actions as well as vs SAC native on-the-fly calculations (Restricted and Calc measures/accounts)?

2. Above will provide real-time planning capabilities similar to what competitors offer without performance and flexibility bottlenecks of SAC native on-the-fly calculations.

3. It will also reduce the delays-to-insight caused by SAC Data Action batch processing, which is currently still a preferred planning calculation tool due to its flexibility, but is lacking real-time-ness.

 

Thank you

Kind regards,

Michael

entry.title: SAP JOULE & ME : My First JOULE Skill in SAP EHSM-Incident Management Without Coding
entry.content:
This blog outlines the SAP JOULE Skill setup for the creation of an EHS Incident . I have leveraged SAP JOULE`s low-code  and no-code capabilities to build something impactful.

Fact Sheet: In SAP`s definition, JOULE is not an acronym. It is the name of SAP`s generative AI assistant. SAP named its digital assistant after "James Prescott Joule", who studied the nature of heat and discovered its relationship to mechanical work. The SI unit of energy, the Joule (J) is named after him.

SAP Joule welcome screen.

 

What is SAP Joule:

SAP Joule is an AI copilot that is grounded in organization`s business data. It aims to understand our requests, retrieve information, and complete our tasks using natural language in a conversational way.

  • Joule Skill :  It is a predefined capability that executes a specific task within the business context.
  • Joule Agent: It is a more advanced AI powered assistant that uses multiple JOULE Skills and other agents to complete complex tasks/workflows.

(In my view, JOULE Skill is like a hand that executes what it is told, and JOULE Agent is like a brain that decides which skill to be used, in what order, and under what conditions. )

SAP Joule supports four main capability types, viz: Informational, navigational, transactional, and analytical.

Disclaimer:  This blog outlines the "Transactional"  capability type and provides a high-level overview of Joule Skill setup. It is not intended to cover the full technical details or advanced configurations of the SAP Joule Skill.

Let us first understand SAP Joule capability types...

  • Informational: An Informational capability (conversational search) helps users retrieve necessary information from SAP Help portal or documents uploaded to the joule service.

 

  • Navigational: A navigational capability helps users find and navigate to the functionality or apps they are looking for without having to go through multiple links to reach a destination. Joule supports navigation to selected core SAP Fiori apps in the Sourcing and Procurement, Finance, Sales, cross-area capabilities (manage Business Partners, My Inbox, etc.), Service Management, Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management. (Source : Finding Apps with SAP Joule Navigational Capability )

Note: A navigational use case may be viewed as a streamlined version of a transactional use case.

  • Transactional: A transactional capability helps users with their day to day tasks. Using transactional capability, joule helps users execute specific business tasks or actions.

 

  • Analytical: An analytical Insights capability helps users explore their data and gain insights into their business, in a natural, conversational experience. It Performs deeper analysis, often combining data sources. (Note: The Joule Skill analytical images are sourced from the SAP Business AI website). Analytical insights are powered by SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

My Business Use Case:

In day-to-day operations, EHS incidents are critical, and We have a policy in place that allows all our employees across the locations to report EHS Incidents (Near Miss, Safety Observation, Incident) based on what they observe at the location. With Joule skill, our users can report incident instantly using a conversational interface, and minimize potential risks to the organization. Once EHS incident is reported, our Incident Manager is notified and it is addressed promptly.

Let us dive into the details...

First things first, let us verify the OData services available for EHS Incident in S/4HANA system. To do this, log in to the SAP API hub and review the EHS Incident OData Service schema to understand the available fields.

Now let us activate EHS Incident OData service in S/4HANA system.

After activating the EHS Incident OData service, we create Action Project. We use action project for creating and display the EHS Incidents via an OData service representing an SAP System.

To do so, choose OData Destinations and create an action project "EHS_Incident_Management".

Now choose required Input and Output fields for this action.

For instance, I have chosen "Incident Title", "Incident Category", "Incident Date and Time" and "Incident Location Description" fields as Input. 

and for output, I have chosen "Incident ID",  "Incident Status",  "Incident Title", "Incident Category", "Incident Date and Time" and "Incident Location Description" fields.

Now let us first test the Action "Create an Incident".

EHS Incident has been successfully created in SAP S/4HANA System.

Now let us save the action project, release and publish.

Now let us create Joule skill. The lobby is a central page for creating, accessing, and managing our projects in SAP Build.

Enter the name and description of the Project.

Now let us create the JOULE SKILL. First things first, we must add the action that was created in earlier step for creating an EHS Incident under "Dependencies" tab.

after adding the dependencies for the EHS Incident Creation, we can now create Joule skill.

The description is very important because Joule will use it to identify the correct skill to select during the conversation.

 

Now let us define the Input and Output parameters for the Joule Skill.

 

For Instance, I have turned off the toggle switch "Allow Joule to generate a response" and configured my own conversation starter to make it easier for my users.

Now let us configure Input fields.

We have configured the parameters. Now let us add the action "Create Incident" that was created.

and we must choose the destination variable for the action.

Now let us map the Input fields using skill content.

Now let us configure the output message that will be displayed after the JOULE skill creates an EHS Incident.

If there are any errors in the Joule skill setup, the system displays them under the "Design Console" tab.

As there are no errors in the EHS Incident Joule Skill setup, we can now Save, Release and Deploy the joule skill.

We can maintain the "Release Notes" to ensure more transparency and avoid ambiguity across Joule Skill versions.

Now let us "Deploy" the Joule Skill.

Now, let us engage with SAP Joule to create an EHS Incident. To do this, we can access the respective environment under "Control Tower" and launch "Joule".

Now, we can either click on the button "Create EHS Incident" or have a conversation with joule to create an EHS Incident. For Instance, let us use the button "Create EHS Incident".

we can now provide the input details

as per our input details, SAP Joule Skill creates an EHS Incident with number "24".

let us check the Incident Number "24" in S4HANA System.

 

Let us ask Joule to provide all the EHS Incidents reported as of today.

 

üòäWith SAP Joule, I was able to setup my first SAP Joule Skill in SAP EHSM-Incident Management using OData Service without coding. It proves that anyone can streamline processes and add value with ease. It was truly transformative.

Stay tuned for more updates on SAP Joule Skills in Asset Management Space...

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy. Chelikam

entry.title: SAP TechEd : Comment √ßa se passe vraiment ?
entry.content:
Un format pens√© pour apprendre et exp√©rimenter

SAP TechEd est l‚Äôune des conf√©rences phare de SAP. Elle est principalement d√©di√©e √† l‚Äôinnovation technique dans l‚Äô√©cosyst√®me SAP. L‚Äô√©v√©nement dure 3 jours et m√©lange diff√©rents formats pour r√©pondre √† tous les profils techniques : d√©veloppeurs, consultants, architectes et experts SAP.

Chaque journ√©e suit un rythme assez similaire. Les participants choisissent librement leur programme parmi des centaines de sessions techniques. Le premier jour fait exception avec deux keynotes. La premi√®re marque le lancement officiel de l‚Äô√©venement. La deuxi√®me, en fin de journ√©e, est d√©di√©e aux annonces sur les nouvelles technologies et aux derni√®res innovations.

Le choix des sessions : √† toi de construire ton agenda !

Contrairement aux autres √©v√®nements, c‚Äôest toi qui choisis. Les inscriptions aux sessions et workshops se font directement sur le site du TechEd ou via l‚Äôapplication SAP Events. C‚Äôest une √©tape importante, car certaines sessions ont un nombre de places limit√©es. Souvent les workshops se remplissent rapidement.

Les formats les plus pertinentes selon moi sont :

  • Sessions Deep Dive : 45 √† 60 minutes pour explorer un sujet en profondeur (ex : ABAP Cloud, SAP BTP, IA, int√©gration, s√©curit√©‚Ä¶)
  • Usability Testing : pour donner son avis sur les nouveaux outils et aider SAP √† am√©liorer l‚Äôexp√©rience utilisateur
  • Roadmap Sessions : pour comprendre o√π SAP va dans les prochains mois
  • Hands-On Workshops : pour tester directement les nouvelles technologies

Les workshops hands-on : le c≈ìur de TechEd

Les hands-on c‚Äôest ce qui rend TechEd unique. Pas seulement de la th√©orie, mais aussi de la pratique avec les experts du produit.
Le d√©roulement classique de tous les workshops:

  1. Tu re√ßois un sc√©nario ou un cas d‚Äôusage √† suivre
  2. Tu acc√®des √† un environnement SAP de d√©monstration qui souvent d√©j√† pr√©configur√©
  3. Tu d√©veloppes ou configures pas √† pas, avec l‚Äôaide d‚Äôexperts
  4. Tu peux poser des questions en live si tu bloques aux responsables du produits.

‚ö†Ô∏èLimite importante : SAP impose souvent un maximum de 2 workshops hands-on par personne. Une petite astuce existe pour en faire plus. Sur place, vous pouvez parfois r√©cup√©rer une place libre le jour J en arrivant en avance. Ce n‚Äôest pas garanti, mais √ßa peut fonctionner.

Certifications

SAP met souvent √† disposition des parcours d√©di√©s, des sessions cibl√©es pour pr√©parer des certifications. A la fin du TechEd des cr√©neaux sont propos√©s pour passer examens sur place.

Ce qui peut √™tre difficile

TechEd est un √©v√©nement technique. Il peut √™tre tr√®s dense pour des profils moins techniques. Autre difficult√© plus op√©rationnels :

  • Les environnements peuvent √™tre lents si beaucoup de monde se connecte en m√™me temps
  • Il faut choisir, et renoncer √† beaucoup de sessions int√©ressantes
  • L‚Äôagenda se remplit vite, surtout pour les workshops

Ce qui peut √™tre int√©ressant

  • Bien se pr√©parer en amont de l‚Äô√©venement en lisant les annonces sur les sessions choisis
  • Si possible, faire quelques exercices sur la BTP

Le vrai plus : les rencontres

Le TechEd, c‚Äôest aussi :

  • Rencontrer les experts SAP que nous avons l‚Äôhabitude de voir en ligne
  • √âchanger avec des personnes qui vivent les m√™mes projets que nous
  • Reconnecter la communaut√© technique dans la vraie vie
  • Partager des id√©es, des difficult√©s, des solutions

entry.title: SAP GUI - Transaction Code - DBACOCKPIT (Active Statements)
entry.content:
last updated: 2026-01-05

Introduction
The article explains the SAP GUI ‚Äì TCODE (Transaction Code): DBACOCKPIT (Active Statements) usage in details.

SAP GUI

  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì SAP GUI for Windows
  • SAP Community ‚Äì SAP GUI ‚Äì SAP GUI Family
  • 147519 ‚Äì Maintenance strategy / deadlines for SAP GUI for Windows / SAP GUI for Java

Description
You can check the "Active Statements" and based on the presented details e.g. long running or resource intensive execution can be identified.

Transaction Code:
DBACOCKPIT 

DBA Cockpit menu structure (Navigation Panel):
Performance > Active Statements

  • SAP Help Portal - DBA Cockpit for SAP HANA - Screen Layout in DBA Cockpit for SAP HANA

Screen: Active Statements
Listing the actually running executions.

Example:
Identify long running or resource intensive execution. In the below example we can see all values shows high numbers.

Details (e.g.):

  • Application Source
  • Allocated Memory Size
  • Used Memory Size (Byte)
  • AVG Execution Time
  • MAX Execution Time
  • etc.

The identified statement can be investigated further (ST04 - - > Performance - - > SQL Plan Cache menu and find the SQL statement hash based on the SQL statement string).

Reference:

  • 3322936 - How to find the SQL statement hash for a SQL statement string

Other articles in this series
üîñ 3428763 - Bookmark of frequently used SAP GUI transaction codes for SAP HANA related investigations

Do you have further questions?
Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have question or observation regarding the article.
SAP Community for SAP GUI: https://community.sap.com/topics/gui

Contribution
If you find any missing information belongs to the topic, please let me know. I am happy to add the new content. My intention is to maintain the content continuously to keep the info up-to-date.

Release Information

Release DateDescription
2026.01.05First/initial Release of the SAP Blog Post documentation (Product Information).

entry.title: üáÆüá≥ Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India )
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on Getting Started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core and Python. You do not need any background in the topic, but you should have a lot of curiosity!

In this CodeJam, you will learn how to use the Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). This approach improves the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduces hallucinations. You will learn how to deploy an LLM and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core, and how to query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Additionally, you will gain insights into key generative AI concepts and learn how to enhance RAG responses.

This is a free in-person event and is planned for Tuesday, January 20th, 2026 in Hyderabad from 09:00 to 15:30 IST. The language of the event and the content will be in English.

The event is kindly hosted by Tekskills India Pvt. Ltd. Thank you!

The instructors are Developer Advocate @Shilpa_Shankar and @sheenamk 

Location: Tekskills India Pvt. Ltd, Survey # 1050, Plot # S - 2, 505 , 5th Floor, Manjeera Trinity, Corporate, JNTU Hi-tech City Road, KPHB 3rd Phase, Kukatpally, Hyderabad, Telangana 500072

Please note that spaces are limited; we can only accommodate 30 attendees. If you wish to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. A few weeks before the event, we will ask you to confirm your attendance.

Prerequisites: Any Chromium-based web browser, such as Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome etc.

Visit the SAP CodeJam group for more information on SAP CodeJam events, to ask questions, and to chat with your fellow attendees.
